column4: I have a question about linux, I know windows has problems with burning audio/movies if you try doing other stuff while its burning, is linux any different with this?
you can do whatever you like, as long as you watch for buffer underruns
I am using serpetine audio creator
dunno anything about it - just give cdrecord or whatever a large buffer and you should be ok
is that a FE to cdrecord?
Im not sure, I dont see anywhere where I can set a buffer for it though
if so, you can specify a buffer size with CDR_FIFOSIZE=whatever in /etc/default/cdrecord
I only use cdrecord
do I run the cdrecord program
you probably can specify the buffer size on the command line (see man cdrecord), but better put it in /etc/default/cdrecord
it shows it as 4megs
I have 8, which is probably overkill
I let cdrecord do as it likes WRT speed
it snot good to write a music cd at 40x though is it?
perhaps not; I find cdrecord's reported speed varies a lot depending on what I'm burning
Oh ok, I was making sure it wasnt going to do that
you need to convert to cdda
man cdrecord has examples for doing this sort of thing; also the cd writing howto at tldp.org
I like cdrecord
I was learning cdrecord, but I never got down to it.  I guess Ill look around for some articles on how to use it.
there's a cd writing howto at tldp.org, and man cdrecord has examples of various things; it helps if you set up /etc/default/cdrecord
man cdrecord has an example of the pipeline for doing that
